div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,128] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, FEBURARY 20, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.p: Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

div.head: THE AUSTRIAN TRAVEL AND INFORMATION BUREAU.
div.p: (Under the Direction of the I. R. AUSTRIAN RAILWAY MINISTRY.) 86. PICCADILLY. LONDON, W.
The most delightful and health-giving resorts for Anglo-Egyptian Officials are the Alpine districts of Austria, which can be reached in a few hours from Trieste.
Excellent Hotels (to suit every pocket) abound situated in high latitudes of great recuperative power specially recommended by doctors for those who have spent a con-siderable time in a hot climate.
Various high Anglo-Egyptian Officials have already engaged villas, rooms at hotels, etc., for the ensuing vacation season.
Shootings and Fishings (at very low prices) can be arranged through the Bureau, also Castles and Villas can be let or sold.
The fullest information as to cost of tours, travelling and on every point will be sent by the Bureau on receipt of request.

div.head: The Nile
div.p: Sir William H. Preece’s paper, read before the Society of Arts on the 1st inst, in which he discusses the measures that ought to be taken to increase the flow and improve the navigation of the Nile between Assouan and Cairo, merits the careful attention of our Irrigation Department. This branch of the Egyptian Administration has hitherto been looked upon as the most efficient that the country possesses. What has it to say to the following impeachment extracted from Sir William Preece’s lecture? “I have seen no evidence whatever of any engineering operations in hand either to maintain the depth or to train the currents so as to keep the channels in their proper course.I havenot seen a dredger at work, but my line of inspection has been confined to Upper Egypt. On the other hand, the des­truction of the banks by the shadoufs is only too apparent. There are no charts of the river, nor is there any systematic survey in hand. I doubt if any other river in the world is so badly treated.” Further on the lecturer proceeds to point out that “thirty thousand tons of valuable mud are lost in the sea every year, and the rise of the bed of the river in the Delta is a very serious question.” It would be interesting to learn what the Department has to say to Sir William Preece’s strictures, and how far it is considered that the improvements he ad­vocates can be profitably undertaken. Surely so serious an indictment as the wanton neglect of Egypt’s single waterway and sole source of fertilisation, or, to adopt Sir William’s words, “the main artery of life and commerce of the country,” calls insistently tor some reply ; and the public mind, greatly disturbed by criticisms coming from so highly qualified an expert, will not be tranquillised without some official reassurance that matters are not so black as they are painted.

div.head: STATE OF RUSSIA.
div.p: GRAND DUKE'S MURDER
THE TSAR'S GRIEF
STRIKES EXTENDING

ST. PETERSBURG, February 18. The Tsar deplores in a manifesto the death, by the wicked hand of assassins, of his Uncle and friend “whose whole life was devoted to the service of ourselves and the Fatherland.” An extraordinary sitting of the Council of the Empire took place to-day in order to con-sider the situation resulting from the assas-sination of the Grand Duke Sergius. The leading Russian papers, while de-nouncing the assassination of the Grand Duke Sergius, declare that the need for reforms is largely responsible, as it promotes the revolu¬tionary propaganda. The town is being flooded with revolutionary literature (Reuter)

ST. PETERSBURG, February 18. The Council of the Empire held an extra-ordinary sittirg on the occasion of the death of the Grand Duke Sergius. A manifesto of the Tsar expresses his grief at the assassination of the Grand Duke, whose every action had been devoted to the service of his country. Every Russian would share in the mourning, and would pray for the deceased. (Havas.)

ST. PETERSBURG, February 19. The alarm caused here by the murder of the Grand Duke Sergius has been intensified by the scattering broadcast of violent revolutionary proclamations. Fresh strike troubles are announced from different parts of Russia. (Reuter.)
LONDON, February 19. The King has ordered Court mourning during a week for the Grand Duke Sergius. (Reuter.)

ST. PETERSBURG, February 18. The strike here is again rapidly extending. 30,000 men have rejoined the strikers, whose temper is now more threatening than during the previous period. The troops have been re-drafted into the vicinity of the works. The police are renewing their domiciliary visits and arresting the leaders. (Reuter.)

ST. PETERSBURG, February 18. The employees of the South Western Moscow-Riazan, Moscow-Kieff-Voroness and Mos- cow-Rybinsk-Windau railways have struck. The traffic on the last line is completely sus¬pended, and the others partially so. (Reuter)

div.head: THE WAR
div.p: RUSSIAN RIVERSE
RUSSIANS SURROUNDED BY JAPS

ST. PETERSBURG, February l8. A Russian correspondent at the front reports that a detachment with two guns, which was pursuing certain Japanese railway cutters on the 13th inst, was surrounded on the 14th by an overwhelming force of Japanese. The Russians suffered heavily and lust one gun. (R.)

St. Petersburg, February 18. A confused despatch from General Kuropatkin confirms the surrounding of a detach¬ment, mentioned this morning. It does not record any loss of any guns but mentions that in the attempt in save them the Japanese were pursued for 20 versts. (Reuter.)
MYSTERIOUS PEACE RUMOURS. ST. PETERSBURG, February 19. Mysterious rumours of peace, which are untraceable from any direct source, have been cropping up during the past few days. (R.)
RUSSIAN PAPERS SUSPENDED, ST. PETERSBURG, February 19. The papers “Nashi Dni" and “Nashi Shizn,” having been warned lor the third time, have been suspended for three months. (Reuter.)
GENERAL STOESSEL. CONSTANTINOPLE, February 19. General Stoessel has arrived here. (Reuter)

RUSSIAN REFORM. ST. Petersburg, February 19. The Committee of Ministers, after deliberating on the ukase of the 25th December, has drawn up some municipal improvements, which have been Sanctioned by the Tsar. M. Kedrine, the lawyer, has been banished to Siberia. (Havas.)

U. S. A. AND CHINA. WASHINGTON, February 19. The Chinese Minister has presented Mr. Roosevelt with a portrait of the Dowager Empress in recognition of America s part in the preservation of Chinese neutrality, and of the country s disinterested friendship. Mr. Roosevelt, replying, emphasized the strong interest of each country in the well-being and advancement of the oilier. (Reuter)

GREEK AUTONOMY. LONDON, February 18. Great Britain, France, Italy, and Russia have presented to Germany and Austria a note practically replying to the memorandum of the 22nd November. It says that the protecting Powers will not tolerate annexation without the consent of the inhabitants, but the wording generally appears to defer the realisation of the Greek hopes indefinitely. The Powers are willing, however, to withdraw their troops. (Reuter.)

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION
div.p: TENDERS for the supply of the undermen­tioned Services at Cairo and Alexandria, will be received at the British Army Head Quarters, Cairo, until 12 o’clock noon on TUESDAY the 28th February, 1905.
{Hospital Supplies, Washing and Repairing Bedding etc. Auctioneering, Conservancy (Cairo only) Remaking Hair Beds (Alexandria only) } For period of three years from 1st April, 1905.
{Bread and Flour, Bran, Fresh Milk, Fuel and Light, Pepper, Conservancy (Alexandria only)} For period of twelve months from 1st April, 1905.
Forms of Tender and information may be obtained on application at the Head Quarter Offices, Cairo and Alexandria.
The General Officer Commanding does not bind himself to accept the lowest or any Tender.
The General Officer Commanding, Cairo,
and marked on the outside “Tenders for.......... ’’
By Order,
Arthur Colville, Colonel, Chief Staff Officer.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: The S.S. “Antwerp City,” on board of which a fire occurred last week, left Alexandria for her destination yesterday.
M. Raoul Pugno’s Pianoforte Recital will takeplace at the New Khedtvial Hotel to­morrow evening, at 9.15 o’clock.
House-Show.—Owing to delay in transmis- sion through the post we are unable to publish our report of the Horse Show held in Cairo ou
Saturday.
Fire.—A fire broke out in the shoonah belonging to the Ottoman Bank at Alexandria at 8.30 o’clock oil Saturday evening. 42 bales of cotton were scorched. The damage is esti­mated at £250.

Germania Lodge.—The charity ball given by the Germania Lodge of Freemasons oil Sa­turday night at Monferrato’s Hal, proved a great success, from 250 to 300 dancers being present. The greatest animation characterised the function, which, we hope, will be the fore­runner of many more of the kind. As our readers are aware, the proceeds of the ball are to be devoted to the purchase of warm cloth­ing for necessitous children of all nationalities.

The Partial Eclipse ol the Moon which took place last nignt was Very clearly visible in this city, the evening being a fine one, and the atmosphere remarkably clear. The moon rose at 5.40, the first contact with the penumbra took place at 6.41 and withthe shadow at 7.54, the middle ot me eclipse was at 9 o' clock exactly, the last contact with the shadow at 10.7 and with the penumbra at 11.19. The magnitude of the eclipse was 0.41 of the moon's diameter, whereas in me partial eclipse of August 15 next it will only be 0.292.

Phenomenal Weather. — As our daily weather reports from Kom el-Nadoura observatory show, the weather at Alexandria for some time past has been quite phenomenal. On Saturday last, at 8 a.m., we touched the nearest point registered to zero since 1888. Atthat hour the thermometer was only 3 degrees Centigrade above zero. The minimum during the 24 hours at Asslout was 1 and Helouan and Ghizen 4 on that dale. Bad weather has been experienced in the mediterranean. The Florio-Rubatino S.S. "Singapore," which was due at Alexandria yesterday at 2 p.m, only arrived this morning at 6 o' clock.
The ALEXANDRIA MURDER.-- The two men

who, as we announced on Saturday, have been arrested on the charge of murdering the woman whose corpse was found in the Mahmoudiyah Canal some weeks ago, have been handed over to the Parquet and the enquiry is still proceeding. The trunk was found in a box in the canal and the head, arms, and legs were discovered close by. The police, when the discovery was made, were aware thatan old woman, about 60 years of age, who used to sell eggs in the Souk el-Cantar, had been missing for some days past. Itwas known that she wore artificial teeth, and when the head of the victim was discovered, the verification of this peculiarity established the identity. Some persons had seen two men wheeling a box by the canal, and the description of the box called(CANT READ) with that which contained the trunk. The murdered woman lived in the Souk el-Berslu(CANT READ), and one of their neighbours recognised the murderers from the description. They both live in the same house as did the victim, and when arrested accused each other of the crime. They are very pour and had been out of work for some time. The woman was evidently murdered for her valuables, as it was known that she had some jewelry and trinkets in her room.

div.head: Waiter Henry Hicks, deceased
div.p: PURSUANT to Act of Parliament 22 and 23 Vict., Cap. 35, Notice is hereby given that all persons having any claims against the Estate of Walter Henry Hicks, late of Cairo (who died on the 14th day of December, 1904, at Cairo, intestate, and to whose Estate Letters of Administration were granted on this day by the above Court to Mrs. Mary Hicks, the widow and relict of the said deceased) are required to send particulars of their claims to the undersigned, on or before the 31st day of March, 1905, alter which date the said Administratrix will proceed to distribute the assets of the said deceased amongst the persons entitled thereto, having regard only to those claims of which she shall then have notice ; and she will not be. liable for any assets so distributed to any person of whose claim she shall not then have bad notice.
Dated this 18th day of February, 1905.
For the Administratrix,
Em. Sciortino,
25455-1 Advocate, Cairo.

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL, LUXOR
div.p: Best and most comfortable, unique for its position on Nile bank. Under German Management. Moderate charges. Patronised by officer of Army of Occupation. Concerts twice daily
25258-41-17 Proprietors:Moroni and Manusardi.

p.note:
SERIOUS ACCIDENT AVERTED.
T.R.H. the Duke and Duchess of Connaught, with the Princesses and H.H. the Khedive, honored the Cairo Horse Show with their presence on Saturday afternoon. Yesterday morning, their Royal Highnesses attended divine service at All Saints’ Church, and in the afternoon they drove out to Ghezireh. On their return across the Nile bridge, what might have been a nasty accident was narrowly averted. The horse of one of the soldiers of the escort was frightened by the noise made by the large motor belonging to Ghezireh Palace, which was drawn up with a number of other vehicles to allow their Royal Highnesses to pass the bridge, and plunged and fell with its rider. A policeman, named Papayanni, rushed up and by great prompti­tude succeeded in getting horse and rider up again just in front of the Royal carriage.
This morning the Duke of Conuaught in­spected the troops at Kasrel-Nil at 9.40 o’clock in the barrack square.
On Wednesday next the Duke and Du­chess will lunch at the Citadel alter the inspection of the troops stationed there.
On Thursday their Royal Highnesses will proceed to Bedmchein before lunch in the steamboat “Misr” and will remain till the evening at Sakkarah.
On or about the 27th inst. their Royal Highnesses, who will probably be accompanied by Sir Wm. Garstin, G.C.M.G., will visit the Cairo Barrage.
The date of their arrival in Alexandria is still uncertain, but it is probable that they will come down in the afternoon of the 27th and leave on March 2 by H. M. S. “Essex” for Cyprus.
Owing to Court mourning for the late Grand Duke Sergius, their Royal Highnesses will be unable to attend any social functions.
MECCA PILGRIMAGE.
A telegram from Mecca states that the Egyptian pilgrimage has arrived at Mecca, the health of the pilgrims being perfect.
The Board of Health at Constantinople has declared the pilgrimage as free from epidemic.
FITZNER QUATUOR.
The second Fitzner Quatuor concert took place at the Khedivial on Friday before a small but appreciative audience. The charity perform­ance next door at the Zizinia Theatre doubtless would account to a certain extent for the absence of some who would otherwise have been present. But the concert-going public of our city require to be spooned with tickets and only buy when pressed to do so. Anyhow, amateur performances are better attended than those of the best European artists. The programme was a very beautiful and highly interesting one and opened with a Quatuor in D Major by a Russian composer, Giazounow. The Andante Allegro led off with a fugue motif followed by a melody which was taken up by each instrument in turn and again replaced by the fugue motif. The Allegretto was noticeable for its pizzicato passages and cadenzas in thirds perfectly played and apparently the performance of one instrument. The Adagio was incomparably the finest movement of the quartet. It seemed an imitation of the weird music of the AEolian harp, and one distinctly heard the storm fined angrily dashing against the strings and the gentle sighing answers of zephyrs wearied out by the unequal contest. The Allegro was a bright finale of feathered songsters twittering gaily after the cessation of the storm. Dvorak’s Lento, entitled ‘Dumky,’ a Czech word, which was untranslatable even to Austrians present, appeared to resemble a Scotch or an Irish lament in its plaintive wailing melody, so much so that we feel sure a Dumky is the expression musically of forlorn love or a desolate hearth. It elicited a hearty encore which brought hack the performers, who played an Andante movement from one of Grief’s quartets, which was played in a masterly way and brought to a finish with an astonishing chord passage of harmonics. Cherubini’s Scherzo, which followed, was a sportive lively number, and then came the “piece de resistance,” Beethoven’s Quartet in E Minor (op. 59 No 2). How can we dare describe the breadth and beauty of this music al giant’s compositions? We cannot do better than refer music-lovers to Sir George’s Grove’s Essay on Beethoven’s instrumental music. Although the hour was late, nearing midnight, the audience was still enthusiastic, and another encore was granted, when a second movement from Grieg’s Quartet was given, a picturesque martial number in which the dash of arms and the sorrowful tunes of mothers and wives wailing for their lost ones followed one another in quick crashing chords and softened subdued passages of impassioned grief. The finish and ensemble of the Fitzuer Quatuor was admirable, so we have confined ourselves to a mere description of the beautiful music they played. It was altogether a feast for music-lovers.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S. S. “Congo,” from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday and is due here tomorrow.
